description:
Drosophila leontia is a species of fruit fly (genus Drosophila) that belongs to the leontia species group. It is native to parts of Asia, particularly in countries like India and Thailand.

Drosophila leontia is a small insect, with a body length typically ranging from 2 to 3 millimeters. Like other Drosophila species, it has a pair of wings and a pair of antennae. The body coloration of D. leontia is generally yellowish-brown, with some darker areas on the abdomen.

This species is commonly used as a model organism in genetic and developmental biology research, owing to its short life cycle, ease of maintenance in the laboratory, and well-studied genetics. Researchers have utilized D. leontia to study various aspects of evolution, behavior, and molecular mechanisms underlying fundamental biological processes.

The genome of Drosophila leontia has been sequenced, providing insights into its genetic composition and evolutionary relationships with other Drosophila species. Ongoing research continues to explore the unique characteristics and potential applications of this fruit fly species in the field of biological sciences.
